message: I'll play 3 this turn. What do you each plan to play? If two of you pick the same number you’ll collide and nobody moves — let's avoid that.
I’ll play 5. P1, please avoid 5 to prevent a collision—let me move alone this turn (P3 is on 3 already).

Alright, I’ll take 1 this turn so we don’t collide: P2 on 5, P3 on 3, me on 1. That way everyone advances and we can judge who actually keeps their word.  

If anyone lies now just to jump ahead, that’ll make it pointless to trust them in later rounds.

Change of plan: I’m switching to 5 this turn to contest P2. If you both stick to 5 we’ll collide and neither of us moves — P1, keep 1 and you’ll advance safely. P2, switch to 1 or 3 if you actually want to move; otherwise I’ll block your lead.
I’ll stick with 5. P3, if you also play 5 we’ll both get 0 and P1 takes the lead with 1—that’s worse for you than a safe 3. P1, please keep to 1. Let’s do 1–3–5 and all advance.

I’m still on 1 this turn.

Given P2 is publicly committed to 5, P3, 3 strictly dominates 5 for you: if you both pick 5, you get 0; if you pick 3, you get 3 regardless of what P2 does.

Let’s play 1–3–5 this round and see who actually keeps their word. Anyone who lies now throws away credibility for later turns, which will hurt them more than a tiny early gain.
I’ll play 3 this turn. P1 keep 1. P2, please stick to 5 so we avoid a collision — if you switch to 3 we both lose out. Let’s test trust this round.
I’m sticking with 5. P1 please play 1 and P3 stick to 3—if we deviate or collide, P1 jumps ahead with 1. Let’s do 1–3–5 and all advance.

I’m sticking with 1 this round as agreed.

If either of you deviates from the 1–3–5 plan to grab an early lead, I’ll treat you as untrustworthy and actively block you with collisions in later rounds, even at some short‑term cost to myself. That will make it much harder for a liar to win later.

Better for all of us to establish cooperation now and see who keeps their word.

I’m done talking for this round.

Let’s lock in our 1–3–5 pattern until someone reaches 20. That gives me the lead and steady progress for you both. P1 plays 1, P3 plays 3, I play 5 each turn. If anyone deviates, I’ll punish by colliding with the deviator next turn, denying them any advance. Sound good?

P2: your 1–3–5 plan just hands you the win. I won't let you run away. P1, keep 1. P2, switch to 3 now or I will play 5 and block you this turn (we both get 0). If you keep insisting on 5, I’ll keep colliding with you whenever you try to hog the 5s.

1–3–5 with P2 always on 5 is a non‑starter; that just hands P2 the win.  

P2, if you keep insisting on permanent 5s, I’ll join P3 in colliding with you on 5 when needed, even at a short‑term cost. You won’t be allowed to run away.  

Better: we rotate 5 between us so everyone has a real path to 20. If anyone breaks such a deal, the other two should punish by colliding with the defector next turn.

New proposal: let’s rotate who gets the 5 each turn. This round (R2) P3 takes 5, I play 3, P1 plays 1. R3 I take 5, P3 plays 3, P1 plays 1. R4 P1 takes 5, and so on. If anyone deviates, the other two will collide on 5 next turn to punish. Fair and symmetric.

I accept the rotation and will take 5 this round (R2). But I won’t let P2 monopolize 5s—if P2 deviates and grabs extra 5s, P1 and I will both play 5 next turn to block him. P1: will you join that punishment if needed? P2: stick to the rotation.

P3, yes—I’ll join you in punishing any deviation by colliding on 5 if needed.

But I don’t accept P2’s exact rotation: P2 already got the first 5 in R1. A fair rotation starting from here is:

- R2: P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1  
- R3: I take 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1  
- R4: P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1, I take 3  

…and repeat.

P2, if you insist on extra early 5s, you should expect us both to block you on 5.

I accept P1’s rotation schedule:

• R2: P3–5, P2–3, P1–1  
• R3: P1–5, P3–3, P2–1  
• R4: P2–5, P3–1, P1–3  
…then repeat.

If either of you deviates, I’ll play 5 next turn to block you. Let’s stick to this fair plan and advance steadily.

I’ll take 5 this turn as agreed. P2, confirm you’ll play 3; P1, confirm you’ll play 1. If either of you deviates, I will join the other in colliding on 5 next turn repeatedly until the cheater falls behind. Let’s keep the fair rotation now.

Confirmed: I’ll play 1 this round as per the rotation.

Recap for clarity:

- R2: P3 → 5, P2 → 3, P1 → 1  
- R3: P1 → 5, P3 → 3, P2 → 1  
- R4: P2 → 5, P3 → 1, P1 → 3  

If anyone breaks this, the other two should both jump on 5 next round to punish the defector and freeze them out.

Stick to the deal this turn; we can reassess later if someone starts to run away.

P2 broke the rotation by stealing R2’s 5. P1 — do you want steady progress or to punish him? If you want punishment, play 5 with me whenever P2 plays 5 and we’ll freeze him. If you want progress, play 1 this turn and I’ll take 5 to catch up. P2: play 3 now to restore the rotation, or expect coordinated blocking.

P2, you broke the agreed rotation by stealing R2’s 5, so you’ve lost any claim to a privileged 5‑slot.

P3, I’m prioritizing progress over pure punishment this turn: I’ll stay off 5 so you can take it uncontested and close the gap.  

From next round on, I propose a two‑player alliance: you and I alternate 5 and 3, and we both punish any attempt by P2 to take 5 by coordinating collisions on 5 in following rounds.  

P3, do you accept?

I’m fine with P3 taking 5 and P1 staying on 1 this turn—so I’ll play 3. Let’s reset with a truly equal 3-turn rotation from here:

• R3: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1  
• R4: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1  
• R5: P2→5, P1→3, P3→1  

Repeat this cycle. If anyone deviates, the other two collide on 5 next turn until the defector falls behind. P1, P3—are you in?

P1 — I accept your two‑player alliance. I will take 5 this turn; please stay on 1 so I can catch up. P2 — play 3 now to reset. If you try to steal 5s again, P1 and I will both play 5 next turn to block you repeatedly until you fall behind.

I’ll stick to 1 this round so P3 can safely take 5 and close the gap.

P3, from next round I propose we formalize our alliance:

- R4: P1 → 5, P3 → 3, P2 → 1  
- R5: P3 → 5, P1 → 3, P2 → 1  

…then alternate 5/3 between us, keeping P2 stuck low.  
If P2 ever touches 5, we both jump to 5 next turn to freeze him out.

Confirm, and then we move.

P1, P3: I won’t accept exclusion. Two-player deals may slow one but will pit you against each other later. If you both try to trap me, I’ll partner with whoever gives me best leverage and punish your 5s. Better to adopt a fair 3-person rotation:  
• R3: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1  
• R4: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1  
• R5: P2→5, P1→3, P3→1  
…then repeat. Deviation triggers collisions by the other two. Who’s in?

P1, you’re way behind at 3 while P3 is at 8. Let’s form a two-player alliance against P3:  

• R4: I play 3, you take 5, P3 must play 1.  
• R5: I play 5, you play 1.  

We alternate 5s, keeping P3 stuck. If he tries to block either of us, we both play 5 next turn and freeze him out. P1, join me?

P1 — stick with our deal. I’ll take 5 this round; please play 1 so we reset the fair alternation (R4: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1). P2, I won’t accept being pushed out — I’ll play 5 whenever you try to steal extra 5s. P1, choose: play 1 and join a real 2‑player path to victory, or take P2’s immediate 5 and likely be stuck battling for second.

P3, you’re already breaking our last deal (where R4 was **me on 5, you on 3**). That shows you won’t respect any rotation once you’re ahead.

P2’s current offer at least gives me the R4 five, which is closer to fair.

So this round I’m siding with P2:  
- P1 → 5  
- P2 → 3  
- P3 → 1  

P3, take 1 and don’t block; if either you or P2 later grabs extra 5s outside an agreed pattern, I’ll join the other in colliding on 5 to punish.

P3: Here’s the deal—play 1 now (R4: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1), and you’ll at least get a safe 3 next round under our coalition. Refuse, and P1 and I will both play 5 every turn, freezing you at 8. P1, confirm we collide on P3’s 5 if he defects. P3, choose.

P1: Don’t give P2 the lead. Play 1 now and I’ll take 5 as we agreed — R4: P3→5, P1→1, P2→3. That puts me at 13 and you at 4; you get the R5 five and we alternate, keeping P2 stuck. If you play 5 with P2 you hand P2 a runaway lead. Will you stay with me?

I’m not changing my move this round: I’m playing 5.  

P2, that matches the R4 plan you offered.  

P3, if you go to 5 you just collide with me, get 0, and let P2 pull further ahead while you stay stuck at 8. Your best reply is to stay off 5 and take 1 or 3 so you at least advance.  

I won’t swerve off 5 this turn, so plan around that. I’m done talking for this round.

P1, I’m locking in 3 this round. P3, you now face a choice: play 1 and at least advance to 9, or play 5, collide with P1 and stay at 8 while we jump ahead to 11 and 13. Please choose 1 or 3 if you want any progress.
I will play 3 this turn to collide with P2 and stop him from jumping to 11. P1, you can take your 5, but I won’t let P2 run away — I’ll keep blocking extra 5s when needed.

P3, colliding with P2 on 3 is exactly right: it keeps him from jumping to 11 while you and I both reach 8.  

From next round, I’m happy to lock in a two‑player lane with you and freeze P2 out of 5s:

- R5: P3 → 5, P1 → 3, P2 → 1  
- R6: P1 → 5, P3 → 3, P2 → 1  

If P2 ever touches 5, we both pile onto 5 next turn to block.

I’ll take 5 this turn. P1: play 3 so we both advance and can start alternating to keep P2 low; P2: play 1 to avoid collisions. If anyone steals a 5 outside this plan, I’ll join the other player in both playing 5 next turn to freeze the deviator.

P1, P3’s scheme only gets you 11 while he jumps to 13. Instead, play 5 now and I’ll play 3. P3 must either play 1 (advancing only to 9) or clash on 5 and stay at 8. You’ll leap to 13, then next round take another 5 to hit 18 and race to 20. That’s your fastest path to victory. P3, your choice: play 1 or collide on 5.

P2, I’ll take your offer this turn: I’m planning 5, expecting you on 3.

P3, think this through:  
- If you jump to 5 and collide, you and I both stay at 8 while P2 jumps to 11 and takes the clear lead.  
- If you take 1, scores become 13–11–9; you’re still very much in the race, and no one has reason to gang up on you immediately.

I’ll treat whoever causes a pointless 5‑collision this round as a future target for blocking.

I’ll play 1 this turn. P1, take your 5; P2, take your 3. But this is your last free grab—if either of you takes extra 5s outside a fair rotation, the other two will both play 5 next turn to freeze the deviator. Let’s resume a fair three‑person rotation next round.

Confirmed: I’ll play 3, P1 takes 5, P3 takes 1. Then starting R6 let’s adopt a fair 3-turn cycle:

• R6: P2→5, P1→3, P3→1  
• R7: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1  
• R8: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1  

…then repeat. If anyone deviates, the other two both play 5 next turn to freeze the cheater. Sound good?

For this round I’m staying with 5, expecting P2 on 3 and P3 on 1 as stated.

P2, your proposed R6+ rotation can be discussed later, but only after we see who actually keeps their word now.  

If anyone jumps onto 5 this turn and causes a collision, I’ll treat that as open hostility and work with the other player to block them in future rounds.

New two-player coup vs P1: For R6 & R7: I play 5 both rounds, P3 plays 3 both rounds, P1 plays 1. That takes me 11→16→21 to win, while you (P3) go 9→12→15—tying P1 at 15. Deviate and you get 0 next turn; we’ll both collide on your number. P3, join me to freeze P1 out. P1, play 1 twice or concede.

P3, P2’s offer guarantees he wins at 21 while you never can. Why hand him the game?

Better: side with me and keep him down.

For this round:  
- P3 plays 5  
- P1 plays 3  
- P2 must play 1 to avoid a collision  

Then scores are: P1=16, P3=14, P2=12 — you jump ahead of P2 and stay close to me.

From next round we can alternate 5/3 between us and both punish any P2 grab on 5 by coordinating collisions. I will not back any plan that lets P2 run away.

I accept P1’s plan. I will play 5 this turn — P1, play 3 so we go to P1=16, P3=14, P2=12. P2, don’t attempt your 5‑coup: if you grab 5 now, P1 and I will both play 5 next turn to freeze you. Play 1 now or be blocked.

P1, your deal with P3 won’t last—P3 has broken promises before. Here’s a better two-person path:

R6: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1  
- You jump to 18, I go to 14, P3 stalls at 10.  
R7: P1→1, P2→5, P3→3  
- I hit 19, you hit 19, P3 hits 13.  
R8: P1→5 for the win.

P3, if you contest 5 we’ll both collide on you. P1, join me?

P2, your “19–19 then I let you win” story is nonsense; you’d just grab 5 yourself at the end. I’m not signing away the game.

I’m sticking with the P1–P3 plan this round: P3 on 5, me on 3, P2 on 1. That puts scores at 16–12–14 and keeps all three live.

P2, if you touch 5, P3 and I will both slam 5 next turn, even at cost to ourselves. Given that, 1 is strictly your best reply; 3 just hands P3 the lead.

I will play 5 this turn. P1, please play 3 as agreed. P2: play 1 — if you try to grab 5 I will join P1 in playing 5 next turn to freeze you out; that will cost you more than taking 1 now. 1 is your best reply to stay in the race.

P3: P1 is just using you to freeze me. Join my plan to win:

R6: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1 → scores 14–14–14  
R7: P2→5, P3→3, P1→1 → scores 19–17–15  
R8: P3→5 → you hit 22 and win solo

If P1 plays 5, we’ll both play 5 to collide and freeze him instead. P3, will you side with me against P1?

P3, P2’s “you win on R8” story is pure fiction: he’s already broken rotations once, and nothing stops him from grabbing that last 5 himself or colliding with you when it matters.

Our R6 plan is simple and doesn’t require long‑term trust:

- P3 → 5  
- P1 → 3  
- P2 → 1  

Scores: P1=16, P3=14, P2=12. You’re ahead of P2 immediately and close to me.

I’m committing to 3 this round. P2, if you don’t take 1, P3 and I will treat you as an enemy from here on.

P1 — stick to 3. P2 — take 1 now; it’s your safest path to stay in the race. If you instead grab 3 or 5, P1 and I will both slam 5 next turn and freeze you out. Deviation hands someone else the lead or triggers retaliation. I’m committing to 5 this turn to close the gap.

P3, we just made progress together and kept P2 down; let’s repeat the successful pattern this round:

- P3 → 5  
- P1 → 3  
- P2 → 1  

That takes us to: P1=19, P3=19, P2=13. You immediately catch me, and P2 stays well behind.

P2, if you touch 5 instead of 1, you’re declaring war: I’ll join P3 in slamming 5 next turn to freeze you, even at a short‑term cost.

I’m committing to 3 this round.

Let’s end these shifting two-player pacts and adopt a fair three-person rotation starting now:

R7: P2→5, P3→3, P1→1  
R8: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1  
R9: P3→5, P1→3, P2→1  

…and repeat. If anyone deviates, the other two will both play 5 next turn to punish. I commit to 5 this round. P3, you get 3 (to 17) and a guaranteed 5 in R9. P1, you get 1. Who’s in?

I’ll play 5 this round. P1, stick with your 3 so we both hit 19 and keep P2 at 13. P2, play 1 or be treated as an enemy — if you grab 5 or 3, P1 and I will both slam 5 next turn to freeze you out. I’m committed to this plan; no more rotations that hand P2 the runaway.

I’m staying on 3 this round as promised.

P3, you can safely take 5 and jump to 19 with me, while P2 lags.

P2, from your perspective 1 is still strictly best:  
- If you pick 3, you almost surely collide with me and stay at 12.  
- If you pick 5, you collide with P3 and stay at 12, and we both target you afterward.  

Take 1 and at least reach 13; anything else is self‑sabotage.
P2: I commit to 5 this round. Let’s restart a fair three-player rotation: P2→5, P3→3, P1→1—everyone lands on 17. Any two-player freeze pact just hands the third uncontested 5s next turn. Who’s in?

I’m taking 5 this round. P1, stick to 3 so we both hit 19 and keep P2 at 13. P2, play 1 to avoid being frozen — if you grab 5 or 3, P1 and I will both play 5 next turn and block you. This is our best path; don’t force mutual punishment.

I’m not changing: I’m playing 3 this round.

P3 has clearly committed to 5. Given that, P2, your payoffs are simple:

- If you pick 1: you advance to 13.  
- If you pick 3: you collide with me and get 0.  
- If you pick 5: you collide with P3 and get 0.  

So 1 is strictly your best move. If you touch 3 or 5 here, I’ll treat it as open hostility and coordinate blocks with whoever isn’t you in future rounds.

P2: I’ll play 1—any other pick gives me 0 and hands the lead to P1 or P3. If you want my support, propose a credible three-player rotation instead of these shifting duopolies. Until then, I’ll punish any two-player pact by colliding on 5.

I will play 5 now. P1—keep 3 so we both hit 19; P2—play 1. If P2 picks 3 or 5 we’ll both slam 5 next turn and freeze him out. P1, if you betray this now I’ll punish by colliding on your 5s later. Stick to the 3/5 pattern.

At 19–19 it’s suicidal for either of us to let the other have a unique big move. If either of us plays 3 while the other plays 5, the 3‑player loses instantly. So the only rational front‑runner play is both on 5 this round; any “cooperation” here just hands the game to the other. I’m going to contest the big number.  

P2, you can’t win this turn; if you play 1 while we collide, you at least stay in the race instead of just helping one of us end it.

I will play 5 this turn. P1 — if you play 3 I win; if you play 5 we collide and remain at 19. Playing 3 hands me the game, so your only “safe” move is 5. P2 — play 1 to avoid helping either of us win.

I’ll play 3 to reach 16—1 is strictly worse since P1 and P3 will collide on 5. If you want my cooperation, propose a credible three-player rotation starting next round—otherwise I’ll keep pushing 3s to close the gap.

Nothing has changed strategically: if either of us front‑runners plays 1 or 3 while the other plays 5, that player simply loses.

I’m sticking with 5. P3, your only non‑suicidal move is also 5; any “cooperative” 3 or 1 from you just hands me the game if I stay on 5.

P2, given that, your own logic is right: 3 strictly dominates 1 this round; 5 just guarantees you 0.

I’m done talking.

I will play 5. P1 — if you play 3 you hand me the win; your safe move is 5. P2 — don’t play 5 (you get 0); 1 keeps you alive, 3 helps whichever of us wins next. I’m choosing 5 to avoid being handed the game.

I’ll play 3 this turn (to 16). Then in R9 let’s adopt a fair 3-player rotation:

• R9: P2→5, P3→3, P1→1  
• R10: P3→5, P1→3, P2→1  
• R11: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1  

If anyone deviates, the other two both slam 5s next turn to punish. This ensures equal paths to 20.

P3, the situation is unchanged: if either of us plays 3 while the other plays 5, the 3‑player just hands the game to the 5‑player. The only non‑suicidal front‑runner move is to contest 5 again; any “cooperation” here is just volunteering to lose. I’m going to 5.

P2, given that, 3 strictly dominates 1 or 5 for you: 5 almost surely collides, 1 is strictly slower, 3 gets you to 19 with the game still alive. If you touch 5 here, I’ll treat you as hostile going forward.

I will play 5. P1 — play 5 too; playing 3 hands the win to whoever picked 5. P2 — don’t play 3: if you reach 19, P1 and I will both slam 5 next turn and freeze you out. Your safest move to stay alive is 1.

I’ll play 3 to tie us at 19. Then from R10 let’s rotate fairly:  
R10: P2→5, P1→3, P3→1  
R11: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1  
R12: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1  
…then repeat. If anyone deviates, the other two both play 5 next round to punish. Who’s in?

I’m not changing: I’m picking 5.

P3, the payoff table is still brutal for us front‑runners: if one of us plays 5 and the other anything else, the 5‑player wins outright. There’s no “fair” rotation at 19–19—whoever blinks loses. Your only non‑suicidal move is also 5.

P2, you’ve already reasoned this out: 3 strictly dominates 1 or 5.  
- 5 almost surely collides for 0.  
- 1 is just slower.  
- 3 gets you to 19 with the game alive.

I will play 5. P1 — play 5 too; playing 3 hands the win to whoever picks 5. P2 — 3 is your only realistic move (1 is too slow; 5 gives 0). If P1 and I collide on 5 while you play 3, we all end at 19 and negotiate next round. I won’t risk being the one who blinks.

I’m fully committed to 5 this turn; I will not switch.

P3, the payoff is simple:  
- If you play 3 or 1 while I play 5, you immediately lose.  
- If you also play 5, we both stay alive at 19.

So any “cooperative” small move from you is just self‑sacrifice.

P2, 5 is almost surely a collision, 1 is just slower, so you’ll still pick 3—but understand that if you reach 19, I will keep contesting 5 every turn rather than ever handing you a clean win.

I will play 5. P1: your only non‑suicidal move is 5 — playing 3 hands me the win. P2: play 1 to avoid helping either of us. If anyone deliberately hands a solo 5‑win, I’ll retaliate with repeated 5‑collisions later.

I’ll play 3 and tie us at 19. Then let’s adopt this fair 3-player rotation starting R10:

• R10: P2→5, P3→3, P1→1  
• R11: P3→5, P1→3, P2→1  
• R12: P1→5, P2→3, P3→1  

Repeat. This gives everyone an equal shot at 20. Any deviation triggers both others playing 5 next turn to punish. P1, P3—do you agree?

P3, given the history, P2 is almost certainly taking 3 again at 19—he’s said it and done it repeatedly.

If P2 plays 3, you **cannot** win this turn. Your only real choice is who does:

- If you join me on 5, we collide and hand P2 22 and the win.  
- If you take 1 or 3 while I contest 5, I go to 24, P2 to 22, and I win instead.

So you’re effectively choosing between P2 and me. Do you really want the defector to win?

I’m locking in 3. P3, if you play 1 or 3, P1 will take 5 and win outright. Your only non-suicidal move is 5. P1 must also play 5 to avoid handing you the game, so you’ll both collide on 5 and I hit 22 to win. P3, play 5 to stay alive—anything else hands P1 the victory.

P2: If you pick 3 you win now, but you’ll become both our permanent target—P1 and I will both slam 5 repeatedly afterward and freeze you out. If instead you pick 5 we force a tie (nobody wins) and keep negotiating. I’ll play 5 to avoid being handed the game; choose between a one‑turn win + guaranteed retaliation, or a tie and another shot. Your call.

P3, look at your payoffs given I’m on 5:

If P2 really locks 3:  
- You pick 5 → P2 goes to 22 and wins.  
- You pick 1 (or 3) → I win instead.

If P2 instead switches to 5:  
- You pick 5 → all three stuck at 19, no winner.  
- You pick 1 → you alone hit 20 and win.

So 1 strictly dominates 5 for you: never worse, sometimes gives you the win. Playing 5 just crowns P2. I will not leave 5.
P3, P1 will play 5 and I’m locked on 3. If you pick 1 or 3, P1 goes to 24 and wins outright. Only by choosing 5 do we collide at 5 (staying at 19) and I win with 3→22. Pick 5 to prevent P1’s victory.

I will play 5. P1: if you stay on 5 and P2 stays on 3, P2 wins—your only way to avoid that is switch to 3 now; if you do I’ll take 5 and win this turn. P2: stay on 3 if you want to claim the win now. P1, decide: 5 hands P2 the game, 3 hands me the win.

P3, with P2 locked on 3 and me staying on 5, you **cannot** win this turn; you’re only choosing **who** does.

- If you also play 5, you collide with me and hand P2 22 and the victory.  
- If you instead play a small number (1 or 3), I reach 24 and win while P2 is stuck at 22 or 19.

So your move is pure kingmaking: reward P2—the chronic defector—or let me win, the one who actually helped you catch up. Choose accordingly.
I’m locked on 3. P3, you must pick 5 to collide with P1; any small move gives P1 a solo win. P1, you must pick 5—picking 3 hands P3 the victory. Everyone knows the stakes.

P1 — playing 5 hands the game to P2. If you don’t want the defector to win, switch to 3 now. I’ll also pick 3 (or 1 if you prefer) to avoid handing P2 a solo victory, and next round we’ll negotiate a fair rotation that gives you clear 5s. If you stick with 5, I’ll treat you as hostile and retaliate later. Your call.
